Yay, that's definitely progress! Try changing the definition of `_GLFW_EGL_NATIVE_WINDOW` in `cocoa_platform.h` to
```c
#define _GLFW_EGL_NATIVE_WINDOW  ((EGLNativeWindowType) window->ns.object)
```
and see if that helps.

body:
@mumin16 ANGLE's support for rendering to windows directly on OSX is extremely bad at the moment. It expects EGLNativeWindowType to be CALayer* and even then introduces extra blits, isn't vsynced etc.

Source: I'm the author of this crappy code and should fix it some day :)
@Kangz Thanks! Do you know if it will expect a CALayer in the future as well or switch to a window or view?

I think it will end up accepting both a CALayer or an NSView like [Swiftshader](https://github.com/google/swiftshader/blob/master/src/Main/FrameBufferOSX.mm#L90). If you think an NSView is better I can make a patch to allow that.
@Kangz I'm fine with whatever variant lets us talk to most (all?) macOS EGL implementations.

FYI this came up in the following forum question along with a potential fix:

http://discourse.glfw.org/t/egl-and-opengl-es-on-mac/1281

issue.body:
The only two EGL implementations on macOS are Swiftshader and ANGLE.
While Swiftshader supports both `NSView` and `CALayer` as
`EGLNativeWindowType`, ANGLE supports only `CALayer`. Furthermore
Swiftshader's OpenGL ES frontend is deprecated in favor of using ANGLE
on top of Swiftshader's Vulkan frontend.

This means that on macOS `EGLNativeWindowType` should be a `CALayer` for
compatibility with ANGLE.

Fixes #1169

body:
Coming back to this (it's been two years >_>) I put up https://github.com/glfw/glfw/pull/1680 and checked locally with a modified `triangle-opengl` that it works correctly with ANGLE. I also fixed retina support for ANGLE's OpenGL backend on Mac [here](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/angle/angle/+/2154670).

Note that the window surface implementation of ANGLE OpenGL on Mac sucks and shouldn't be relied upon, but in the future the Vulkan (on swiftshader) or Metal backends on Mac should have good window surface implementation.
